curated_text: Symbol: INTC. Year: 2022. Period: Q3. ReportType: Q10. Section: Competition and Market Position. This section discusses competitors, market dynamics, and regulatory landscape.  Competitors mentioned: the European Commission, EC, Advanced Micro Devices, Inc., AMD, Statement, the European Economic Area Agreement, the Court of First Instance, the General Court, the European Court of Justice, Intervener Association for Competitive Technologies, Intel, The Court of Justice, the Court of Justice, The General Court, the Court of Justice’s, the General Court's, Litigation Related to, Google, GPZ, the Superior Court of Justice of Ontario, the Superior Court of Justice of Quebec, the District Court, Board of Directors, the Superior Court of the State of California, The California Superior Court, Board, the California Court of Appeal, the California Superior Court, the Superior Court, Institute of Microelectronics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, the Institute of Microelectronics of, the Chinese Academy of Sciences, Intel China, Ltd., Dell China, Ltd., Beijing Jingdong Century Information Technology, Ltd., the China National Intellectual Property Administration, CNIPA, the Beijing Intellectual Property, IP, The Beijing IP Court, the Supreme People's Court, the Beijing IP Court's, SPC, IMECAS, the Beijing IP Court, the United States Patent & Trademark Office, Inter Partes Review, USPTO, IPR, the Patent Trial and Appeal Board, Lenovo (Beijing) Co., Ltd., Lenovo, Beijing Jiayun Huitong Technology Development Co. Context excerpt: Competition Matter In 2001, the European Commission (EC) commenced an investigation regarding claims by Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (AMD) that we used unfair business practices to persuade customers to buy our microprocessors. We received numerous requests for information and documents from the EC and we responded to each of those requests. The EC issued a Statement of Objections in July 2007 and held a hearing on that Statement in March 2008. The EC issued a Supplemental Statement of Objections in July 2008. In May 2009, the EC issued a decision finding that we had violated Article 82 of the EC Treaty and Article 54 of the European Economic Area Agreement. In general, the EC found that we violated Article 82 (later renumbered as Article 102 by a new treaty) by offering alleged "conditional rebates and payments" that required our customers to purchase all or most of their x86 microprocessors from us. The EC also found that we violated Article 82 by making alleged "payments to prevent

We received numerous requests for information and documents from the EC and we responded to each of those requests. The EC issued a Statement of Objections in July 2007 and held a hearing on that Statement in March 2008. The EC issued a Supplemental Statement of Objection
